article.headline: USC 67, California 47
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- California wanted to play basketball, even
though the Golden Bears' hearts and thoughts were elsewhere.

Southern California defeated Cal 67-47 Friday night in the
Bears' first game since reserve Alisa Lewis died earlier this week.

"It was very difficult," guard LaTasha O'Keith said. "We keep
thinking about her."

Cal coach Caren Horstmeyer broke down sobbing afterward.

"That team has a ton of heart," USC coach Chris Gobrecht said.

There was a moment of silence before the game to honor Lewis,
who died Monday of bacterial meningitis, an infection of the
covering of the brain and spinal cord.

Lewis died hours after complaining of a severe headache, rash
and flulike symptoms. Cal's players decided to go ahead with their
road trip after getting reassurances from Lewis' parents.

"She would have wanted us to play," guard Kristin Iwanaga
said. "We played hard and that's what she always did."

During the national anthem, Cal's players and staff stood
shoulder-to-shoulder across the court holding hands.

Cal players wore small black square patches on the front of
their jerseys with AL 31 in pink, Lewis' favorite color. The team's
coaches and staff wore pink ribbons with Alisa #31 on them.

The game notes were dedicated "in loving memory to Alisa Marie
Lewis," and her career and season highs were highlighted in a box.

"Teams are so close. It's every coach's and every team's worst
nightmare to go through what Cal is going through," Gobrecht said.
"That young lady could have been any one of our teammates in the
Pac-10."

Gobrecht was particularly touched because she has a teenage
daughter.

"Twenty-five years of coaching, I've gone to bed every night
dreading a phone call like that," she said.

The Golden Bears (9-8, 2-6 Pac-10) never challenged the Trojans
in losing their fourth straight. They shot 17 percent from the
floor in the first half, committed 22 turnovers and trailed 30-10
at the break.

"It was a very heartfelt game out there. You could tell by
their faces," said USC's Ebony Hoffman, who had 15 points. "You
could tell they were ready to play, but something within them just
didn't feel right out there. The second half felt a little bit
better, but the underlying factor was they still were a little bit
heartbroken."

The Bears played the Trojans evenly in the second half, with
each team scoring 37 points. Cal improved its shooting to 53
percent from the floor and had just eight turnovers in the final 20
minutes.

"The second half felt better," forward Leigh Gregory said.
"We were able to focus a lot more and kind of get back in our
rhythm. That's the hardest thing right now is getting back in the
rhythm of normal daily life."

Cal's point total was its lowest this season. The Bears hadn't
scored less than 50 points since they had 35 against Stanford last
March. Nihan Anaz scored 14 points.

"Everything right now is a little bit difficult for us,"
O'Keith said, clutching a tissue.

USC (9-7, 6-2) was led by Rometra Craig with 19 points.

"The first half was a struggle," Horstmeyer said. "The second
half you saw more of our team."

Lewis, a 20-year-old junior forward, played in 10 of the Bears'
16 games before her death. She averaged 1.9 points and 1.7
rebounds. She started six games during her first two years.

About 1,000 people attended Lewis' memorial service Thursday in
Berkeley, including Stanford coach Tara VanDerveer and Washington
coach June Daugherty. The Cal athletic department has established a
women's basketball scholarship in Lewis' name.

In Cal's media guide, Lewis listed her favorite inspirational
quote: "Dream as if you'll live forever, live as if you'll die
today."

Lewis' death was the second brush with tragedy for USC's team.
Last season, Washington's Kayla Burt nearly died days before the
Huskies traveled to Los Angeles for a game against the Trojans.

Burt's heart stopped beating and teammates kept her alive with
CPR until help arrived. She was diagnosed with a rare electrical
disorder that causes heartbeat irregularities and was forced to end
her career.
